intro: Phacelia imbricata, commonly known as the Sierra phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its blue to purple flowers and hairy stems. The plant typically grows in rocky or open habitats, often in mountainous regions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Phacelia imbricata plays a role in supporting pollinators and is sometimes used in ecological restoration projects.
